paragraphs.text:
%md
# About This Lab
**Objective:** To become familiar with how files are added to and removed from HDFS and how to view files in HDFS.
**File locations:**
**Successful outcome:** You will have added and deleted several files and folders in HDFS.
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** The Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)

---

msg.data:
About This Lab

Objective: To become familiar with how files are added to and removed from HDFS and how to view files in HDFS.
File locations:
Successful outcome: You will have added and deleted several files and folders in HDFS.
Before you begin:
Related lessons: The Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)
Setup

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the data from S3
paragraphs.text:
%sh
rm -f Rev6.zip
rm -f data.txt
rm -f small_blocks.txt
rm -f -R DevPH_Labs-Rev6
wget https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/sci-241/HortonworksUniversity-DevPH_Labs-archive/Rev6.zip
unzip Rev6.zip
mv DevPH_Labs-Rev6/labs/Lab2.1/data.txt .
mv DevPH_Labs-Rev6/labs/demos/small_blocks.txt .
hdfs dfs -test -d test && hdfs dfs -rm -R test || echo ""

Lab

paragraphs.title: 1 - View the hdfs dfs Command

paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice that the usage contains options for performing file system tasks in HDFS, like copying files from a local folder into HDFS, retrieving a file from HDFS,
copying and moving files around, and making and removing directories. 
In this lab, you will perform these commands, and many others, to help you become comfortable with working with HDFS.

Enter the following command to view the contents of the user’s zeppelin directory in HDFS, which is /user/zeppelin
~~~
hdfs dfs -ls
~~~

msg.data:
Notice that the usage contains options for performing file system tasks in HDFS, like copying files from a local folder into HDFS, retrieving a file from HDFS,
copying and moving files around, and making and removing directories.
In this lab, you will perform these commands, and many others, to help you become comfortable with working with HDFS.

Enter the following command to view the contents of the user’s zeppelin directory in HDFS, which is /user/zeppelin

hdfs dfs -ls

paragraphs.title: 2 - View the content of the zeppelin user directory in HDFS
3 - View the content of the root directory in HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Important**

Notice how adding the / in the -ls command caused the contents of the root folder to display, but leaving off the / showed the contents of /user/zeppelin, which is the default prefix if you leave off the leading / on any of the hadoop commands (assuming the command is run by the “zeppelin” user).

msg.data:
Important

Notice how adding the / in the -ls command caused the contents of the root folder to display, but leaving off the / showed the contents of /user/zeppelin, which is the default prefix if you leave off the leading / on any of the hadoop commands (assuming the command is run by the “zeppelin” user).

paragraphs.text:
%md
Enter the following command to create a directory named test in HDFS:
~~~
hdfs dfs -mkdir test
~~~

msg.data:
Enter the following command to create a directory named test in HDFS:

hdfs dfs -mkdir test

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a directory named test in HDFS
5 - Verify that the folder was created successfully

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a couple of subdirectories for test:
~~~
hdfs dfs -mkdir test/test1
hdfs dfs -mkdir -p test/test2/test3
~~~

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a couple of subdirectories for test

paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice how the -p command can be used to create multiple directories. The second command above will fail if you omit the -p.

msg.data: Notice how the -p command can be used to create multiple directories. The second command above will fail if you omit the -p.

paragraphs.title: 7 - View the contents of /user/zeppelin

paragraphs.text:
%md
Notice you only see the test directory. To recursively view the contents of a folder, use -ls -R:
~~~
hdfs dfs -ls -R
~~~

msg.data:
Notice you only see the test directory. To recursively view the contents of a folder, use -ls -R:

hdfs dfs -ls -R

paragraphs.title: 8 - View the contents of /user/zeppelin recursively

paragraphs.text:
%md
Delete the test2 folder (and recursively, its sub-contents) using the -rm -R command:
~~~
hdfs dfs -rm -R test/test2
~~~

msg.data:
Delete the test2 folder (and recursively, its sub-contents) using the -rm -R command:

hdfs dfs -rm -R test/test2

paragraphs.title: 9 - Delete a directory
10 - Confirm the deletion of the directory

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note**

Notice Hadoop created a .Trash folder for the zeppelin user and moved the deleted content there. The .Trash folder empties automatically after a configured amount of time.

msg.data:
Note

Notice Hadoop created a .Trash folder for the zeppelin user and moved the deleted content there. The .Trash folder empties automatically after a configured amount of time.

paragraphs.text:
%md
We have downloaded some files on your local file system as part of this lab setup.
We fill use them to test the upload to HDFS.

msg.data:
We have downloaded some files on your local file system as part of this lab setup.
We fill use them to test the upload to HDFS.

paragraphs.title: 11 - Check the content of  data.txt

paragraphs.text:
%md
Run the following -put command to copy data.txt into the test folder in HDFS:
~~~
hdfs dfs -put data.txt test/
~~~

msg.data:
Run the following -put command to copy data.txt into the test folder in HDFS:

hdfs dfs -put data.txt test/

paragraphs.title: 12 - Copy data.txt into the test folder in HDFS
13 - Verify that the file is in HDFS by listing the contents of test

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now copy the data.txt file in test to another folder in HDFS using the -cp command:
~~~
hdfs dfs -cp test/data.txt test/test1/data2.txt
~~~

paragraphs.title: 14 - Copy a File in HDFS
15 - Verify that the file is in both places by using the -ls -R command on test
16 - Now delete the data2.txt file using the -rm command

paragraphs.text:
%md
You can use the -cat command to view text files in HDFS. 
Enter the following command to view the contents of data.txt:
~~~
hdfs dfs -cat test/data.txt
~~~

msg.data:
You can use the -cat command to view text files in HDFS.
Enter the following command to view the contents of data.txt:

hdfs dfs -cat test/data.txt

paragraphs.title: 17 - View the Contents of a File in HDFS
18 - You can also use the -tail command to view the end of a file

paragraphs.text:
%md
See if you can figure out how to use the get command to copy test/data.txt from HDFS into your local /tmp folder.

paragraphs.title: 19 - Getting a File from HDFS
20 - Put the file small_blocks.txt into the test folder in HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%md
You should now have two files in test: data.txt and small_blocks.txt.
Run the following getmerge command:
~~~
hdfs dfs -getmerge test /tmp/merged.txt
~~~

msg.data:
You should now have two files in test: data.txt and small_blocks.txt.
Run the following getmerge command:

hdfs dfs -getmerge test /tmp/merged.txt

paragraphs.title: 21 - Run a getmerge command

paragraphs.text:
%md
What did the previous command do? Did you open the file merged.txt to see what happened?

msg.data: What did the previous command do? Did you open the file merged.txt to see what happened?

paragraphs.text:
%md
Put data.txt into /user/root in HDFS, giving it a blocksize of 1,048,576 bytes.  
**Hint:** The blocksize is defined using the dfs.blocksize property on the command line.

paragraphs.title: 22 - Specify the Block Size and Replication Factor

paragraphs.text:
%md
Run the following fsck command on data.txt:
~~~
hdfs fsck test/data3.txt
~~~

msg.data:
Run the following fsck command on data.txt:

hdfs fsck test/data3.txt

paragraphs.title: 23 - Run fsck on the last file

paragraphs.text:
%md
How many blocks are there for this file?

msg.data: How many blocks are there for this file?

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Result
**You have now:** You should now be comfortable with executing the various HDFS commands, including creating directories, putting files into HDFS, copying files out of HDFS, and deleting files and folders.

---

msg.data:
Result

You have now: You should now be comfortable with executing the various HDFS commands, including creating directories, putting files into HDFS, copying files out of HDFS, and deleting files and folders.
Solution

paragraphs.title: 1 - View the hdfs dfs Command
paragraphs.text:
%md
~~~
hdfs dfs
Usage: hadoop fs [generic options]
	[-appendToFile <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-cat [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-checksum <src> ...]
	[-chgrp [-R] GROUP PATH...]
	[-chmod [-R] <MODE[,MODE]... | OCTALMODE> PATH...]
	[-chown [-R] [OWNER][:[GROUP]] PATH...]
	[-copyFromLocal [-f] [-p] [-l] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-copyToLocal [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-count [-q] [-h] <path> ...]
	[-cp [-f] [-p | -p[topax]] <src> ... <dst>]
	[-createSnapshot <snapshotDir> [<snapshotName>]]
	[-deleteSnapshot <snapshotDir> <snapshotName>]
	[-df [-h] [<path> ...]]
	[-du [-s] [-h] <path> ...]
	[-expunge]
	[-find <path> ... <expression> ...]
	[-get [-p] [-ignoreCrc] [-crc] <src> ... <localdst>]
	[-getfacl [-R] <path>]
	[-getfattr [-R] {-n name | -d} [-e en] <path>]
	[-getmerge [-nl] <src> <localdst>]
	[-help [cmd ...]]
	[-ls [-d] [-h] [-R] [<path> ...]]
	[-mkdir [-p] <path> ...]
	[-moveFromLocal <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-moveToLocal <src> <localdst>]
	[-mv <src> ... <dst>]
	[-put [-f] [-p] [-l] <localsrc> ... <dst>]
	[-renameSnapshot <snapshotDir> <oldName> <newName>]
	[-rm [-f] [-r|-R] [-skipTrash] <src> ...]
	[-rmdir [--ignore-fail-on-non-empty] <dir> ...]
	[-setfacl [-R] [{-b|-k} {-m|-x <acl_spec>} <path>]|[--set <acl_spec> <path>]]
	[-setfattr {-n name [-v value] | -x name} <path>]
	[-setrep [-R] [-w] <rep> <path> ...]
	[-stat [format] <path> ...]
	[-tail [-f] <file>]
	[-test -[defsz] <path>]
	[-text [-ignoreCrc] <src> ...]
	[-touchz <path> ...]
	[-truncate [-w] <length> <path> ...]
	[-usage [cmd ...]]

Generic options supported are
-conf <configuration file>     specify an application configuration file
-D <property=value>            use value for given property
-fs <local|namenode:port>      specify a namenode
-jt <local|resourcemanager:port>    specify a ResourceManager
-files <comma separated list of files>    specify comma separated files to be copied to the map reduce cluster
-libjars <comma separated list of jars>    specify comma separated jar files to include in the classpath.
-archives <comma separated list of archives>    specify comma separated archives to be unarchived on the compute machines.

The general command line syntax is
bin/hadoop command [genericOptions] [commandOptions]
~~~

paragraphs.title: 22 - Specify the Block Size and Replication Factor
23 - Run fsck on the last file

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Answer:** The file should be broken down into two blocks

msg.data: Answer: The file should be broken down into two blocks

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
